Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Annual Meeting of the West Coast Bacterial Physiologists to be held in Pacific Grove, CA. December 11-13, 2015 and December 9-11, 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Conference award will help to offset registration costs for advanced undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to attend the 2015 and 2016 West Coast Bacterial Physiologists Meeting. At this meeting, approximately 90% of the talks will be presented by undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral fellows. Junior Faculty initiating their research programs will be invited in order to facilitate their integration into the broader scientific community. The scientific focus of the meeting, foundational aspects of microbial physiology, will be relevant to biotechnological applications (bioremediation, biofuels), metabolomics and other systems-level -omics approaches, genome to phenome studies, and synthetic biology. Meeting organizers will work towards a gender and minority balance in lecturers and conveners.

The West Coast Bacterial Physiologists Meeting will be held in December of 2015 and 2016 at the Asilomar Conference Center in Pacific Grove, California. The meeting will be organized into four scientific sessions over a three-day period. Each of the four sessions will begin with an invited "John Ingraham Lecturers in Microbial Physiology" which will span the range of microbial physiology fields and include new and emerging topics (including genome to phenome relationships, computational modeling, advanced DNA sequencing methodologies). The meeting program and abstracts will be made publicly available on the meeting website. The meeting will give young researchers the opportunity to give an oral presentation at a scientific conference, and will help to integrate junior Faculty into the research community, which will create new collaborative research opportunities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was used to support the 2016 and 2017 Annual Meetings of the West Coast Bacterial Physiologists, which were held at the Asilomar Conference grounds in Pacific Grove, CA. Funds were specifically used to subsidize the costs of attendance by graduate, undergraduate, and psotdoctoral students.

 

In both years, the meetings consisted of four formal and three informal sessions with a broad focus of basic and biomedical bacterial physiology, ecology, genetics and genomics. The formal sessions were chaired by 4 principal investigators (2 female, 2 male).  There were 30 (2016) and 25 (2017) offered presentations of 15 min each in the formal sessions. The three informal sessions consisted of small group discussions at which students could interact with senior scientists one-on-one or in small groups.

 

The 2016 Annual Meeting of the West Coast Bacterial Physiologists was held on December 9-11. There were 132 attendees, including 24 postdoctoral fellows, 49 graduate students, 21 undergraduate students and 27 principal investigators.

Three invited individuals presented John Ingraham overview lectures: Rachel Whitaker, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, “Virus-Host Dynamics in Human Island Populations”, Caroline Harwood, University of Washington, "Bacterial Longevity", and Huiying Li, University of California Los Angeles, “Human Skin Microbiome in Health and Disease”.  The other invited speaker was unable to attend due to family illness. Each invited speaker gave a 40 min presentation. One of the speakers was a junior investigator, and two were senior investigators; all three invites speakers were women.

Thirty abstracts were submitted. Of these, 13 presentations were by graduate students, 8 by postdoctoral fellows and 3 by undergraduates. Of the 132 attendees, Principal investigators represented 20% of the attendees, which provided a good number of highly interested individuals to formally and informally critique the student presentations, as well as provide mentoring on a number of relevant topics during informal sessions.

 

The 2017 Annual Meeting of the West Coast Bacterial Physiologists was held on December 15-17. There were 104 attendees, including 19 postdoctoral fellows, 38 graduate students, 12 undergraduate students and 21 principal investigators.

Four invited individuals presented John Ingraham overview lectures: Katrine Whiteson, University of California, Irvine, “Phage Dynamics in the Gut ”, Jim Imlay,  University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign, “Molecular Mechanisms for the Toxicity of Oxygen”, Nick Shikuma, San Diego State University, “Induction of Animal Metamorphosis by Bacteria”, and Ann Dekas, Stanford University, “Organic matter utilization by Thaumarchaeota”.  Each gave a 40 min presentation. Three of the speakers were junior investigators, and one was a senior investigator; by gender, they represent 2 females and 2 males.

Twenty-six abstracts were submitted. Of these, 12 presentations were by graduate students, 11 by postdoctoral fellows and 3 by undergraduates. Of the 104 attendees, Principal investigators represented 20% of the attendees, which provided a good number of highly interested individuals to formally and informally critique the student presentations, as well as provide mentoring on a number of relevant topics during informal sessions.
